Avantage 4.2: "Les bénéfices économiques totaux qui peuvent découler de la mise à disposition de données publiques peuvent s’élever, selon la Commission européenne, à 40 milliards d’euros par an . Le potentiel
économique ne réside pas seulement dans la réutilisation d’informations du secteur public pour de
nouveaux produits et services, mais aussi dans des gains d’efficacité dans les services publics."

Avantage 4.3: Publication of raw data to better understand decisions and actively participate in policy debates "La transparence des pouvoirs publics est décisive pour la participation citoyenne. Dans une vraie démocratie, les
citoyens prennent part au débat sociétal sur la base d’informations correctes qu’ils peuvent utiliser
pour analyser des choix politiques, poser des affirmations et examiner des faits. Comme les pouvoirs
publics ne savent pas toujours ce qui est pertinent pour le citoyen, les données brutes doivent aussi
être mises à disposition. "
at federal level open data task force and transparency committee for administrations + allow anyone to request access to datasets, similar initiatives/governance at regional level

practical considerations: sometimes demand for opening up data comes top-down, sometimes driven bottom-up, and so is the structure of the governance + political landscape with strong Regions and projects by larger cities
While there are cooperations on open data initiatives and projects, due to the political landscape, the federal level has no authority over open data projects on regional level
All 3 Regions have open data initiatives + a few larger cities (smaller cities require support of Regional level)

Part of Royal Decree and explained in the policy document, action 7 (open data taskforce + data champions in transparency committee https://data.gov.be/sites/default/files/public/content/compressed_fr-strategisch-dossier.pdf)
Explained in Royal Decree, chapitre 4 (https://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/eli/arrete/2019/06/02/2019013333/justel#LNK0004)
Same team: Maintainers of the data portal (open data task force) is also part of Transparency Committee
"open data champion" role per federal public service, responsible for the development of an open data strategy within their administration + participate in transparency committee
About 3 meetings / year with open data portal owners (local/regional/federal level): https://data.gov.be/fr/dcat-groupe-de-travail
Participation in yearly open data event "OpenBelgium" (https://2022.openbelgium.be/), and 1-to-1 (private) online meetings with small companies / NPOs and ICT sector federation Agoria
Only for Statistics and Cadaster data, eg. https://statbel.fgov.be/fr/calendar
Things can always be improved, but a few promosing key-datasets (address register of all 3 Regions combined, extra cadaster data / statistics) have been published, so there is progress

If a federal public body wants to publish data with additional constraints, including costs, the motivation and details have to be sent to the open data taskforce for advice. Art 7, Royal Decree https://www.ejustice.just.fgov.be/eli/loi/2016/05/04/2016009236/justel
N/A
N/A

1) Chicken-and-egg-problem (businesses want "as much data as possible" before they can prove their idea works, public services have limited resources and need to know what to prioritize first + are looking for examples to justify their efforts), 2) Somewhat overlapping data initiatives and regulations (e.g. INSPIRE, ITS,Europeana, PSI... have slightly different goals) , 3) Finding recurring budget for a few high value datasets (maps, historical weather data),
On chicken and egg problem: projects like combined address register with (also) clear benefits for administrations as a "teaser" to encourage administrations to publish more data
"Open data checklist", see top of https://data.gov.be/fr/info-faq
At the regional level / SMARTcities projects, for instance Flanders Region City of Things (https://www.flandersinvestmentandtrade.com/invest/en/sectors/digital-industry/smart-cities)
Part of Inspire / geo.be. With mapping of Inspire to GeoDCAT-AP, geo-spatial data owners don't have to enter metadata twice and become more aware of open data (re)use
Some citizen-science projects like sharing weather data: https://www.meteo.be/en/about-rmi/observation-network/wow-be

Justification:
At the national level, there are sessions (https://data.gov.be/fr/news/seance-dinformation-donnees-ouvertes-services-federaux) and trainings on data in general (though not part of a specific data track) like satellite data (https://terrascope.be/en/news-events/register-our-new-terrascope-webinars) which are open to servants and private sector.
At the regional level, there are trainings, e.g.http://www.futurocite.be/ouvrirmaville/ouvrir-ma-ville-2023/

OpenBelgium (https://2022.openbelgium.be) and OpenSummerOfCode (https://osoc.be/editions/2022, though the 2023 edition is postponed),  CitizensOfWallonia (https://www.citizensofwallonia.be/), OpenStreetMap events (https://osmcal.org/event/1349/), BootCamp Open Cultural Data (https://meemoo.be/nl/vormingen-en-events/bootcamp-open-culturele-data-2023-6e-editie), Webinars on satellite data (https://terrascope.be/en/news-events/register-our-new-terrascope-webinars)
Meemoo (https://meemoo.be), Futurocité, DigitalWallonia

Use of non-private data in an easy (for automated tools) to process format by businesses, NPOs or other administrations than the administration publishing the data, in practical tools, services, visualisations or analyses

Answer: yes, but the focus is limited
Justification: Since the data is open, it is hard to actually get a good idea of the amount of reuse

Yearly search for thesises published with/about open data (https://data.gov.be/nl/studies-en-thesissen) and looking for reuse (also on regional level, see https://www.vlaanderen.be/datavindplaats/inspiratie)
Hard to really measure re-use (some statistics on API-usage perharps, but end-users can distribute full downloads or act as a proxy etc)

Ongoing study "LODE" by cities of Ghent and Bruges (funded by Flemish Region) to verify which data provides the highest economic and social return https://datalab.stad.gent/group/9/stream

Another study for the Flemish Region: https://assets.vlaanderen.be/image/upload/v1675244048/Impact_Open_Data_Vlaanderen_2022_-_Eindrapport_c4nap2.pdf
Participation of public sector experts in OpenKnowledge community, and in activities like "open summer of code"

1-1 meetings with small companies by BOSA (1 per month)
N/A
Brussels region has regular "user club" meetings on UrbIS open geodata: https://paradigm.brussels/fr/quoi-de-neuf/actualites/a-l2019ecoute-de-nos-utilisateurs-2013-users-club-urbis?set_language=fr
Statbel DataLabs https://statbel.fgov.be/en/news/statbel-datalab
Rather on an ad-hoc basis
As far as I know no hard figures, though impact is mentioned in projects and initiatives

Sharing of cadastral parcel plan + statistics and police / emergency zones on  as open data (as opposed to a closed data source) reduces the administrative burden for municipalities and other administrations needing this data https://finance.belgium.be/en/experts-partners/open-data-patrimony/datasets/download-portal)

Same for portals like the Datavindplaats of the Flemish Region which also focuses on reuse by other administrations (https://www.vlaanderen.be/digitaal-vlaanderen/nieuwsberichten/eerste-versie-datavindplaats-gelanceerd), and the Brussels Region (https://datastore.brussels/web/)

Monthly overview of expenses by federal government (https://bosa.belgium.be/fr/budget-de-letat) provides transparancy on spending of tax payer's money, similar initiative in Brussels Region on public procurement expenses(https://openbudgets.be.brussels/en/data-table/table-1), Flanders Region (see also press article https://www.knack.be/nieuws/belgie/politiek/subsidieregister-laat-zien-dat-het-tijd-is-voor-een-kerntakendebat/) and in Walloon Region (https://subventions.wallonie.be/home.html)

Draft legislation of parliament (federal and regional) is sometimes used on social media for discussion

Federal Planning Bureau, https://www.plan.be/indicators/indicators_list.php?lang=en is using and publish open data for the Europe 2020 Indicators, e.g http://www.be2020.eu/index.php?lang=en, used in inflation forecasts and other predictions

"Provinces in figures", combining various open data sources to allow citizens and local politicians to compare statistics on e.g demographics, housing, poverty, vacant real estate, energy use … with other municipalities https://provincies.incijfers.be/dashboard so they can launch plans to improve the local economy and society.

Same for BEP Namur which focuses on improving the economic and social environment for the region of Namur, publishing and analysing open data helps in promoting the region and make policy decisions (https://data.bep.be/pages/accueil/)

There is data on social challenges, eg part of SDG indicators (gender equality, risk of poverty...) https://indicators.be/en/t/SDG/, though hard to say what the impact of open data is on these challenges

Dashboard on the number of displaced persons from Ukraine, which is a tool developed and used by several public administrations to better register and support these people https://statbel.fgov.be/en/visuals/displaced_persons_Ukraine

Also data from openstreetmap is used to improve accessibility for e.g. people with wheelchairs (see this open summer of code project: https://help.osoc.be/osoc22/projects-partners/onwheels)

Articles in media based on statistics like https://statbel.fgov.be/en/themes/housing/real-estate (https://www.dewereldmorgen.be/artikel/2022/01/19/het-onmogelijke-recht-op-huisvesting/), but also in studies like "Does the renovation policy increase the wealth inequality" https://www.scriptiebank.be/sites/default/files/thesis/2022-10/Masterproef_Ward_Brichau_0.pdf

For instance a news item of the statistics office,  based on the survey on income and living conditions (EU-SILC) https://statbel.fgov.be/en/themes/households/poverty-and-living-conditions/risk-poverty-or-social-exclusion#news which was picked up by the media (e.g. https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2023/02/16/risico-op-armoede-of-sociale-uitsluiting/), greatly increasing the awareness of this problem.

University of Louvain-la-Neuve "UCLouvain is committed to making open access, open data and open source common practices mastered in the scientific community." https://uclouvain.be/en/discover/open-education-open-science.html
Reviewer 2 Comments: Please clarify the use of open data (the practical cases) that follows from these commitments

Justification: There is data on climate and environment (like satellite data), but not about impact of this data on the challenges (https://climat.be/)

Flemish institute is collecting and publishing data on the GBIF biodiversity platform (https://oscibio.inbo.be/datasets/), which in turn helps researchers to monitor the current state of biodiversity.

Interregional air quality center (IRCELINE) is actively using open sensor data to monitor air quality (https://www.irceline.be/nl/luchtkwaliteit/emissies/IIR2022.pdf)
Reviewer 2 Comments: the GBIF biodiversity platform is a means to make open data more accessible but is not a reuse case

Justification:
Companies like AnyWays are using open data to offer better mobility services to companies and public administrations to reduce travel time and promote greener options https://www.anyways.eu/blog/2022-09-14-gipod

Regions also provide locations of public charging stations as open data to promote the switch from ICE to EV (https://www.vlaanderen.be/lokale-besturen-en-publieke-laadinfrastructuur)

Walloon Region has the "Wallonie-en-poche" apps which combines various open data sources into 1 app for citizens, e.g. for finding bike-sharing services https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Svvcnr_WQI
The FutureProofed Platform uses closed and open data sources to help municipalities and companies to create a climate plan (https://www.futureproofed.com/cities/benefits)
In Walloon Region energy operator ORES is publishing open data (https://www.ores.be/open-data)
Reviewer 2 Comments: Publishing open data is not an example of reuse; reuse is what people do with the data that is made available

Response to reviewer: Improvement of mappings in back-end tool, see also https://github.com/Fedict/dcattools/issues/121
Every 6 months there is a full review of all the mappings based on the results of the validator. In between there can be smaller fixes and enhancements which are listed on github.
In addition, new potential sources (other portals) are identified and contacted for being harvested (or checked if they are already been harvested by regional portals)

Please describe the process.

2022 Answer:
"Every 6 months or so, the metadata mappings are reviewed based on the results of the validator, 
then either the source or the portals then improves the mappings and/or provide additional metadata.
In addition, new potential sources (other portals) are identified and contacted for being harvested (or checked if they are already been harvested by regional portals)"

Not on a national level (though the Flanders Region has their own license framework, and some federal administrations have their own (old) license but are considering (or per law have to) switching to CC

E.g. internal presentation for federal data managers on open data (https://data.gov.be/fr/presentations), a tailored event for spokespersons to explain what open data is and how it can be used by e.g. data journalists (encouraging them to publish more machine-readable data complementary to annual reports etc). See also https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7057715491078828032/
